Liberty Elementary School
June 4 at 12:50 PM ·

Fifth and sixth grade students from across the district were challenged to put their reading and writing skills to use by creating artifacts for a personal time capsule. Arianna Benner and Abaigeal Garverick, sixth grade students from Liberty Elementary, took the project a step further and chose tangible items that could be placed in a small time capsule.

One item Abaigeal included was a small American Paint horse replica. In her description she said, "This object is important to me because I recently lost my own American Paint and this small horse is very similar. Her name was Hope.”

Arianna included a very special book from her grandmother. She explained, "It's full of quotes about being a granddaughter. When you look inside, it makes you feel teary and when you look on the outside, it makes you feel joy and comfort. It's like everything around you just falls into place."

The Southern Tioga Education Association (STEA), members of the teachers’ union, purchased personal hygiene items and diapers to be shared with food banks in Blossburg, Liberty, and Mansfield.

Our local food pantries are meeting the hunger needs of our students by continuing to supply food, but students no longer have access to the ‘Care Closets’ located in our buildings,” said James Bogaczyk, STEA Union President and fifth grade teacher at Warren L. Miller Elementary.

Throughout the year, teachers donate items such as toothpaste, deodorant, soap, etc. for students to take from the ‘Care Closet.’ To continue to offer these items even after the school closures, the teachers selected the Bloss Holiday Market as a local supplier and purchased all of the donation items from that store.

Thank you to STEA for continuing to support our learning community - inside and outside of the the classroom!!

We appreciate your patience and understanding as we work together to create meaningful remote learning opportunities for all students.

We know the coronavirus has created challenges for AP students and teachers. Here’s how the College Board will support you during this time:

To support AP students affected by school closures due to COVID-19, students and schools will have access to live AP review lessons, delivered by AP teachers from across the country. Lessons will begin March 25.

2️⃣ We’re developing a new at-home testing option

Because of the challenges created by COVID-19, we’re developing a new at-home AP Exam option. Students will be able to test on a computer, tablet, or smartphone.

We will invest so that every AP student impacted by COVID-19 has the tools and connectivity they need to review AP content online and take the exam from home.

During this challenging time, we will work to give every AP student the opportunity to earn the college credit and placement they’ve been working toward all year while maintaining a focus on the health and safety of our AP community.
